Brandon Shores Aqueous Ammonia RMP

2016 Update



Facility Overview



The Brandon Shores Power Plant, owned by Brandon Shores LLC and operated by Raven Power Fort Smallwood LLC (Raven), is located near Baltimore, Maryland in northern Anne Arundel County. It is a fossil fueled electric generating facility consisting of two 650 megawatt coal fired units. To improve air quality, and comply with Maryland Healthy Air Act requirements, pollution control technology called selective catalytic reduction (SCR) was installed in 2001 to reduce NOx (nitrogen oxides) emissions by 90%.



SCRs use ammonia to react with the NOx in the combustion gas to form harmless nitrogen gas and water. Because the safety of Raven employees and the surrounding community is of utmost concern, Brandon Shores primarily uses technology that generates ammonia from urea on an as-needed basis. Urea is a less hazardous solid that can react to form ammonia on-site. This reduces transportation risks and minimizes onsite storage quantities of ammonia. Because the urea-to-ammonia technology had not been fully proven when the SCR was under design and construction, Brandon Shores also has a 30% aqueous ammonia system that is available as a backup system in case the urea system is out of service due to operational problems or for maintenance. The SCR ammonia system is kept approximately 60% full for use when the urea system is not operational to support year round operation of the SCR with minimal disruptions.



The SCR aqueous ammonia system consists of three 18,000-gallon storage tanks surrounded by a dike wall. The aqueous ammonia is pumped form the storage tanks to a vaporizer which uses steam to heat the ammonia solution converting it into a vapor. The ammonia vapor is mixed with air and injected into the SCR. The ammonia vapor reacts with the NOx in the presence of the catalyst to form harmless nitrogen gas and water vapor.



Safety features include:



- Diked/protected storage and unloading areas;

inimized and safety features were incorporated that go beyond industry standards including the remote controlled tank isolation valves, ammonia monitors, and a surveillance camera. 

- Operating procedures - Standard operating procedures and safe work practices are strictly followed.

- Training - All Raven technicians are qualified on applicable operating and maintenance procedures, safe work practices, and emergency response procedures. An emergency response HAZMAT team qualified at the Operator level is present on-site at all times. The drivers of the ammonia trucks are trained on the plant specific unloading and emergency response procedures.

- Preventive maintenance - A preventive maintenance and inspection program has been developed to ensure the ongoing mechanical integrity of the system.

- Change management - Change management procedures have been implemented to ensure proper materials of construction, safety evaluation, and updating of operating and maintenance procedures.



Accident History



The Brandon Shores facility has never experienced a reportable release or accident associated with the storage or use of 30% aqueous ammonia. 



Emergency Response Program



Brandon Shores has a detailed Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan that includes specific emergency response procedures, procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies, and first aid and emergency medical treatment information for ammonia exposure. The emergency response procedures have been provided to the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) for distribution to the local emergency planning and response organizations as needed. The local fire department has toured the facility many times and a comprehensive tour was provided for all local emergency response agencies in July 2013.



All plant personnel are trained on emergency response procedures. A HAZMAT team trained to the Operator level is on-site at all times. Emergency response drills are performed

semi-annually.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Brandon Shores significantly improved the safety of the ammonia feed system for the SCR since submittal of the original RMP in 2001 by installing and operating a urea-based system that generates ammonia as needed.
